bestBHT.bht: Jesus continues His discourse by explaining the impending actions of the Lord of the vineyard. He reveals that the Lord will come and destroy the husbandmen, ultimately entrusting the vineyard to others. This response serves as a direct answer to the question posed by the chief priests, Scribes, and elders. The following events can be further explored in the corresponding verses of Matthew.

Henry Alford: He will come, &c., is...a continuation of our Lord's discourse.
After ver. 11 comes in Matt. vv. 43-45.
John Gill: What shall therefore the Lord of the vineyard do?"
...he will come and destroy the husbandmen, and will give the vineyard unto others.
This is an answer to it, given by the chief priests, Scribes, and elders.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 12:9, the verse is a continuation of Jesus' discourse, specifically responding to the question of what the Lord of the vineyard will do. Jesus emphasizes that the Lord will come and destroy the husbandmen, giving the vineyard to others. This response serves as an answer to the chief priests, Scribes, and elders who challenge Jesus. Additionally, it is worth noting that the events following this verse are recorded in Matthew verses 43-45.

Continuing His discourse, Jesus explains that the Lord of the vineyard will act in response to the question posed. He will come and destroy the husbandmen, transferring the vineyard to others. This is His answer to the challenge presented by the chief priests, Scribes, and elders. It is worth noting that in Matthew, the events that follow are recorded in a passage spanning verses 43-45.

Continuing His discourse, Jesus gives an answer to the chief priests, Scribes, and elders. He explains that the Lord of the vineyard will come and destroy the husbandmen, giving the vineyard to others. This response highlights the consequences of their actions. It is also worth noting that the events following can be found in Matthew, specifically in verses 43-45.

Jesus continues His discourse by explaining the impending actions of the Lord of the vineyard. This response serves as a direct answer to the question posed by the chief priests, Scribes, and elders. The following events can be further explored in the corresponding verses of Matthew.

Continuing His discourse, Jesus addresses the question by explaining that the Lord of the vineyard will come and destroy the husbandmen, transferring the vineyard to others. This response directly confronts the challenge presented by the chief priests, Scribes, and elders. The subsequent events can be found in the corresponding verses in the book of Matthew.
